data.description: Springs, streams, lakes - whatever its form, water is the attraction at Chickasaw National Recreation Area.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter Chickasaw National Recreation Area.
entranceFees.title: Chickasaw NRA Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: From US I-35 drive through the towns of Davis and towards the town of Sulphur. There are a variety of destinations in the park to choose from.

operatingHours.description: Many outdoor areas are available 24 hours a day. Please visit the current conditions page for details.
operatingHours.name: Outdoor Areas

images.title: Lincoln Bridge
images.altText: Lincoln Bridge with Travertine Creek flowing below
images.caption: Lincoln Bridge stands out as one of the oldest park structures

images.title: Lake of the Arbuckles
images.altText: Lake boating on a summer day
images.caption: Lake of the Arbuckles attracts many boaters each summer for various recreational activities

images.title: Family Fishing Fun
images.altText: Lake fishing with family
images.caption: Learning to Fish at Veterns Lake

images.title: Park Bison
images.altText: Herd of bison
images.caption: The park has a herd of bison which are very popular

images.title: Hiking to Buffalo Springs
images.altText: Two people hiking over a water feature
images.caption: Two people walk towards Buffalo Springs, one of the park's many fresh water springs

data.weatherInfo: Summers are hot and humid. Temperatures above 100ºF occur, and humidity often exceeds 50%. Winters are mild and prolonged freezes are rare. Thunderstorms are common April through July.
data.name: Chickasaw

data.description: Explore life on the edge of frontier and Indian Territory through the stories of soldiers, the Trail of Tears, scandals, outlaws, and lawmen who pursued them. From the establishment of the first Fort Smith on December 25, 1817, to the final days of Judge Isaac C. Parker's jurisdiction over Indian Territory in 1896, Fort Smith National Historic Site preserves almost 80 years of history.

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee is for individual admittance into the exhibits inside the visitor center building. Your receipt will be good for seven days from the time of purchase. There is no fee for viewing the grounds.
entranceFees.title: Entrance walk in - per person

entrancePasses.description: The annual pass allows the pass holder and 3 adults (16 and older) free entrance to all the exhibits in the visitor center. The pass is valid for 12 months from the month of purchase, expiring the last day of that month.
entrancePasses.title: Fort Smith National Historic Site Annual Pass

data.directionsInfo: From Interstate 40 Eastbound: Exit at Roland, and drive six miles on highway 64 to downtown Fort Smith. From Interstate 40 Westbound & from North I 540 & Fayetteville, take Interstate 40 westbound to I 540 south. Exit west on Rogers Ave. and continue to downtown. In the downtown area: On Rogers or Garrison Ave turn south at 4th St. Turn right onto Garland Ave. At the end of the next block is the entrance to the main parking lot. Parking is also available on Third Street.

operatingHours.description: Park grounds are open from 30 min before sunrise and 30 minutes after sunset.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds and Trails

operatingHours.description: The Commissary is considered the oldest building in Fort Smith. The Gallows is a replica built on the site of the original gallows.
operatingHours.name: Gallows and Commissary

images.title: Visitor Center
images.altText: Aerial view of visitor center
images.caption: The former barracks, courthouse, and jail serves as the park's visitor center

images.title: Commissary and Supply Wagon
images.altText: Commissary and Supply Wagon
images.caption: In 1845, Fort Smith was converted to a supply depot. With this mission, Fort Smith became one of the busiest supply posts in the southwest.

images.title: Entrance sign
images.altText: Entrance sign in snow
images.caption: Entrance sign along the river trail on a snowy day.

images.title: Foundations of First Fort Smith
images.altText: Foundations of first Fort Smith and Arkansas River
images.caption: Foundations of the first Fort Smith with Arkansas River in the background

images.title: Jail Wagon and Gallows
images.altText: Jail Wagon and Gallows
images.caption: A jail wagon like this one was use the transport prisoners to the Federal Courthouse 6th Street.

images.title: Supply Wagon and Visitor Center
images.altText: Supply Wagon and visitor center
images.caption: Supply Wagon and visitor center

data.weatherInfo: Fort Smith weather includes four distinct, yet temperate seasons. Spring and fall are usually mild while late summer is hot and humid. During winter months, temperatures occasionally dip into the teens. Forecast often changes dramatically due to surrounding weather influences. Arkansas's central location allows weather systems from all directions to influence its climate. The area is prone to flash flooding and river flooding in rainy seasons.
data.name: Fort Smith

data.description: The outdoor symbolic memorial is a place of quiet reflection, honoring victims, survivors, rescuers, and all who were changed forever on April 19, 1995. It encompasses the now sacred soil where the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building once stood, capturing and preserving forever the place and events that changed the world.

entranceFees.description:
There is no fee to visit the Outdoor Symbolic Memorial. 

There is, however, a $15.00 to enter the Oklahoma City National Memorial and Museum which is owned and operated by the Oklahoma City National Memorial Foundation.
entranceFees.title: Oklahoma City National Memorial: Outdoor Symbolic Memorial Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: The Memorial & Museum are located at 6th St. and Harvey Ave in Oklahoma City, OK.

operatingHours.description: The Outdoor Symbolic Memorial is open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, all year long.
operatingHours.name: Oklahoma City National Memorial: Outdoor Symbolic Memorial

operatingHours.description: Please visit www.memorialmuseum.org for hours of operation and to purchase tickets.
operatingHours.name: The Oklahoma City National Memorial Museum

images.title: Children's Area
images.altText: Tiles with hand prints and chalkboards set into the ground for children.
images.caption: This area provides letter shaped chalkboards to allow the continued emotional expressions from those young and old. A surrounding wall displays a collection of painted tiles sent by schools, showing their compassion for the bombing-affected community

images.title: Memorial Fence
images.altText: Fencing with pictures, stuffed animals and other tokens left on it.
images.caption: This 200 foot section of chain link fence was taken from the original barrier surrounding the bombing site. The fence served as the first spontaneous memorial and a location for people to leave tokens of collective grief. It retains this purpose still to

images.title: Summer Nights
images.altText: Summer evening photo of the Memorial lit up at night
images.caption: Beat the summer heat, on an evening stroll through the illuminated Field of Empty Chairs, the Gates of Time, and the Survivor Tree. All walkways are brightened to allow enjoyment of this peaceful time of day.

images.title: Snow on Empty Chairs
images.altText: Snow covered Field of Empty Chairs
images.caption: The Memorial becomes a silent place during the rare winter snow storms that blow through. The cold and quiet house a stillness made for reflection as one walks through the Field of Empty Chairs.

images.title: Rescuers' Orchard in Fall
images.altText: Bright Red Chinese Pastiche tree in the Rescuers' Orchard.
images.caption: This Chinese Pastiche is located in the small orchard that was planted in recognition of the over 12,000 rescue workers who responded to the bombing. Its vibrant hues draw attention to the tremendous work these heroes accomplished.

data.weatherInfo: Summers are very warm with temperatures averaging mid-high 90’s. Also, be mindful of the heat index. Spring weather brings mild temperatures, 60’s-70’s, but the ability to produce severe storms that could include heavy rains, strong winds, hail, and tornadoes. While winters are generally mild delivering temperatures in the 30’s and 40’s, the wind chill can be brutal. No matter the season you are planning to visit, be prepared for the winds to be gusting.
data.name: Oklahoma City

data.description: You can almost hear the whoops and cries of "All's set!" as trail hands hitched their oxen to freight wagons carrying cargo between western Missouri and Santa Fe, New Mexico. Follow the Santa Fe National Historic Trail through five states and you'll find adventure and evidence of past travelers who made this remarkable trip before you!

entranceFees.description: There are no user or entry fees for the Santa Fe National Historic Trail. Fees may be charged at some trail-related federal, state, or locally owned historic sites and interpretive facilities. Please contact individual trail sites before visiting for more information.
entranceFees.title: Entrance fees vary site by site

data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the Santa Fe National Historic Trail over the 900-mile historic route that crosses five states.

operatingHours.description: There are many places of history and commemoration on the Santa Fe National Historic Trail to visit. Museums, interpretive centers, and historic sites provide information and interpretation. Please contact each site before you go to obtain current information on closures, changes in hours, and fees.
operatingHours.name: Santa Fe National Historic Trail

images.title: Cimarron National Grassland
images.altText: Warm light from the setting sun gives an orange glow to a rock bluff overlooking a grassland.
images.caption: Visit Cimarron National Grassland to experience the Santa Fe Trail.

images.title: Neosho River Crossing, Council Grove
images.altText: A wide river with green grass parks on the side.
images.caption: The Neosho River in Council Grove was an important crossing on the trail.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site, La Junta, Colorado
images.altText: emigrant wagons pulled by oxen and horses cross the prairie with people walking alongside
images.caption: After spending weeks crossing hundreds of miles of lonely and desolate prairie, a trading post appeared: a welcome respite where travelers could repair their wagon and trade for coffee, sugar, blankets, and ammunition.

images.title: Wagon Mound, Mora County, New Mexico
images.altText: desert landscape with a mountain that looks like a wagon from a distance, verdant green grasses
images.caption: Wagon Mound was a landmark on the Santa Fe Trail. Coming from Raton, New Mexico, travelers looked for this wagon-like hill to know that they were close to Santa Fe. Leave Interstate 25 at the village of Wagon Mound in Mora County to find this landmark.

images.title: Fort Union, New Mexico
images.altText: A stone path leads into the distance next to adobe ruins.
images.caption: The Santa Fe Trail traverses through Fort Union.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Santa Fe National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: Santa Fe

data.fullName: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
data.description: Remember and commemorate the survival of the Cherokee people, forcefully removed from their homelands in Georgia, Alabama, and Tennessee to live in Indian Territory, now Oklahoma. They traveled by foot, horse, wagon, or steamboat in 1838-1839.

entranceFees.description: There are NO USER OR ENTRY FEES fees for the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail. NOMINAL FEES may be charged at some trail-related federal, state, or locally owned historic sites and interpretive facilities. Please visit Plan Your Visit / Places To Go for an interactive map and extensive list of places to visit by state. Contact information is available for each site to call and find out about fees.
entranceFees.title: General Entrance Fee Information

data.directionsInfo: You can visit many of the sites along the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail over the 2,200+ mile route that crosses 9 states.

operatingHours.description: OPERATING HOURS VARY FROM SITE TO SITE. There are many historic sites, museums, and parks (federal, state, and local) along the Trail of Tears in Tennessee, North Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Kentucky, Illinois, Arkansas, Missouri, or Oklahoma for you to visit. Please contact individual sites for more information by going to Plan Your Visit and selecting Places To Go or Passport Program, where sites are listed by state, and there is an interactive map to search for sites.
operatingHours.name: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail
Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

images.title: Chieftain's Museum, Rome, Georgia
images.altText: large white house, green lawn, two trees in front
images.caption: The museum tells the story of Major Ridge, the influential Ridge family including prominent son John Ridge, Cherokee history, and the Trail of Tears, as well as subsequent history of the home and region.

images.title: Brown's Ferry Tavern, Chattanooga, Tennessee
images.altText: structure in the background with large chimney on the end; signs saying Brown's Ferry Tavern
images.caption: Cherokee leader John Brown, who owned 640 acres in this area, ordered the construction of Browns Ferry Tavern in 1803. In 1838, the road running past this structure was the route by which several Cherokee detachments were removed to present-day Oklahoma.

images.title: Mantle Rock Preserve, Joy, Kentucky
images.altText: sunlight coming through trees with green leaves
images.caption: Thousands of Cherokee camped for weeks along the main (northern) route, near Mantle Rock, during the winter of 1838-39 as they waited for ice conditions in the Ohio River to allow a safe crossing.

images.title: Cherokee Retracement at Pea Ridge National Military Park, Garfield, Arkansas
images.altText: dozens of people walk a section of the Trail of Tears, winter scene, trees with no leaves
images.caption: The Pea Ridge National Military Park encompasses 4,300 acres and features a visitor center, museum, self-guided tours, reconstructed Elkhorn Tavern, and a retracement trail along a 2.5-mile original route segment of the Trail of Tears.

images.title: Grave Stone of William Adair, Stilwell, Oklahoma
images.altText: gravestone with words etched, green grass
images.caption: When the Cherokee arrived at their prescribed disbandment depot in Oklahoma, settlements sprang up nearby. There was a depot at the Adair's farm near present-day Stilwell, Oklahoma.

images.title: Crabb Abbott Farm, Grantsburg, Illinois
images.altText: Two people walk a remnant of the Trail of Tears. Spring setting with green leafed trees.
images.caption: Crabb Abbott Farm has segments of the Northern Route, including the rock crossing and ford of Sugar Creek. These segments are contiguous with trail segments on the adjacent Shawnee National Forest.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: www.weather.gov
data.name: Trail Of Tears

data.description: On November 27, 1868, Lt. Colonel George Armstrong Custer led the 7th US Cavalry on a surprise dawn attack on a Cheyenne village led by Peace Chief Black Kettle. The event was an example of the tragic clash of cultures that occurred during the Great Plains Wars. It is also a place of remembrance and reflection for those who died here.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to Washita Battlefield National Historic Site
entranceFees.title: Fee Free Park

data.directionsInfo: Washita Battlefield is located just west of Cheyenne in western Oklahoma approximately 130 miles west of Oklahoma City and 140 miles east of Amarillo, Texas; just 25 miles north of I-40 on State Highway 283. From Cheyenne head west on State Highway 47 for about 1 mile and then make a right on State Highway 47A. The visitor center will be on the right and the battlefield is about .5 miles past the visitor center on the right as well.

operatingHours.description: The overlook and trail of Washita Battlefield National Historic Site are open 30 minutes before sunrise and close 30 minutes after sunset.
operatingHours.name: Overlook and Trail

images.title: Tipis at Sunset
images.altText: Cheyenne tipis backlite by sunset
images.caption: Cheyenne tipis backlite by sunset

images.title: Washita River
images.altText: The Washita River in winter covered in ice and snow
images.caption: The Washita River looking much the same as it did during the attack on November 27, 1868

images.title: Cheyenne Dog Soldier Telling Stories
images.altText: A Cheyenne Dog Soldier tells stories inside his tipi
images.caption: A Cheyenne Dog Soldier tells stories inside his tipi

images.title: The Washita Battlefield National Historic Site Visitor Center
images.altText: The Washita Battlefield National Historic Site Visitor Center on a summer day
images.caption: The Washita Battlefield National Historic Site Visitor Center on a summer day

images.title: Learning Something New at Washita
images.altText: A Park Ranger knells down among Junior Rangers so only his hat shows within the crowd of children.
images.caption: A Park Ranger helps children with their Jr. Ranger books.

images.title: "Meeting the Enemy"
images.altText: A Cheyenne Warrior and U.S. Cavalry soldier hold a meeting next to a tipi
images.caption: A Cheyenne Warrior and U.S. Cavalry soldier hold a meeting next to a tipi

data.weatherInfo: Weather in western Oklahoma can vary considerably. Winters can be mild to severe with ice storms being the biggest concern. Spring is usually short but pleasant although severe weather, including tornadoes, is still a possibility. Usually a strong breeze is associated with spring weather. Summers are brutally hot and visitors should be cautioned about spending any length of time in the heat. Falls are cool with a bitter wind.
data.name: Washita Battlefield
